text: the foundations of modern India were
built on one basic principle the right
to vote over the coming weeks people in
every corner of this land will decide on
its future
we traveled deep in the Himalayas to the
district of Kannur which borders China
to meet sean/sharan leggy at 102 he's
India's oldest voter to him this
election matters more than most to grow
we need unity and everyone needs equal
sean/sharan neji's voted in every poll
since this country gained independence
but this election sees India at a
crossroads like many other nations it's
facing increasing nationalism and
division some say the very idea of India
is at stake more than a thousand miles
east from Canora to Kolkata from old to
young many wonder if this country's
become less tolerant first-time voters a
part of the country's growing street rap
scene with more than half of India under
the age of 25 the voice of the
Millennial majority matters more than
ever
Seifer love car leads songs focus on
growing religious tensions between
Hindus and Muslims disappearing I don't
want my India to become a country where
people are fighting amongst each other
walking again you disturb work son blame
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi for
the country's divisions
it's Hindu nationalist BJP party swept
to power in 2014 in a landslide victory
this elections being seen as a
referendum on his time in office his
supporters say he's been a strong man
who's protected India's interests at
home and abroad others say the better
days he promised never arrived in the
last five years
unemployment's risen to its highest for
nearly half a century even so this
country's advanced under Prime Minister
Modi it's the world's fastest growing
major economy set to overtake the UK but
India is characterized by deep divides
elections are the one time the country's
powerless can send a message to those in
power are they happy with the way things
are going
or will they vote for change Rajini
Weiden arvind BBC News Kolkata
